DOC.brief_summary: The investigator test hypothesis transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation ( TENS ) may attenuate peripheral vasoconstriction improve blood flow redistribution handgrip exercise acute myocardial infarction ( AMI ) patient Coronary Arterial Bypass Graft Surgery ( CABG ) .
DOC.brief_title: Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation Improves Vascular Conductance After Coronary Artery Bypass Graft Surgery
DOC.detailed_description: Thirty-eight patient randomize ( 4 times/day ; 30 min/session ) 5-day program TENS ( n = 20 ) placebo-TENS ( P-TENS , n = 18 ) apply cervical region ( C7-T4 ) . Acute sympathetic stimulation cold pressor test ( CPT ) , Maximal voluntary contraction ( MVC ) , Femoral blood flow ( FBF ) femoral vascular conductance ( FVC ) measure primary outcome pre post-CABG , even 6-minute walk test ( 6-MWT ) , Inspiratory expiratory muscle strength ( PImax PEmax ) Î²-endorphin secondary clinical parameter . In addition , amount opioid analgesic pain intensity also measure throughout first 24 hour CABG ( immediately , 6 , 12 24 hour ) .
DOC.criteria: previous history 1 vessel coronary artery disease , lifelong abstinence tobacco , formal indication CABG , accord establish guideline . Patients older 70 year age , chronic renal failure , unstable angina 48 h prior CABG , moderate severe valve disease , complex cardiac arrhythmia , stroke , and/or inability exercise lower limb .
